name: Bhakri
history: Bhakri is a traditional unleavened Indian bread, commonly consumed in western and central parts of India. It's known for its simplicity and is often made from millet, wheat, or rice flour, making it a staple in many Indian diets.
description: Bhakri is a round flatbread, typically thicker than a chapati or roti. It's made using whole grain flour and is cooked on a griddle until it develops a crispy texture. Bhakri is often served with curries, chutney, or vegetables.

ingredients.item: whole wheat flour (or millet/rice flour for gluten-free option)

instructions.title: Prepare the Dough
instructions.description: In a mixing bowl, combine the flour and salt. Gradually add water and knead to form a stiff dough. Let it rest for a few minutes.

instructions.title: Roll the Bhakri
instructions.description: Divide the dough into small balls. Using a rolling pin, roll each ball into a circle, thicker than a regular roti.

instructions.title: Cook the Bhakri
instructions.description: Heat a griddle or tawa over medium heat. Place the rolled bhakri on the griddle. Cook each side until it gets a golden brown color. Optionally, brush with ghee or oil.

instructions.title: Serve
instructions.description: Serve the bhakri hot with your choice of curry, dal, chutney, or vegetables.

nutrition.calories: 80 per serving (varies based on size and ingredients)

tips: The dough should be kneaded well to make the bhakri soft.
Cooking on a low flame ensures even cooking and a crispy texture.
variations: Add herbs or spices to the dough for additional flavor.
Use different types of flour like bajra (millet) or jowar (sorghum) for variety.

storage.shelfLife: Best consumed fresh. Can be stored for 1 day.
storage.instructions: Store in an airtight container at room temperature.

reheatingInstructions: Reheat on a griddle or in a microwave until warm.
presentationTips: Serve on a traditional thali for an authentic experience.
Garnish with a side of pickles and a wedge of lemon.
